div1.p: United States District Court, Western District of Washington, Norhtern Division.
In the Matter of the Application of Antonio Bisegna, alias Disegna, for Writ of Habeas Corpus. } No. 2679 Return and Answer to the Petition for and the Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Comes now Henry M. White, United States Commissioner of Immigration, and as an answer and return to the petition and writ alleges as follows:
I. That he denies each and every allegation set forth in the petition for the writ of habeas corpus, save and except what is hereinafter specifically admitted.
II. That he denies the allegations set forth in paragraph I of said petition.
III. That he admits the allegations set forth in paragraph II, ending at the words "said country" in line 21.
That he admits the allegations commencing at the words "that on April 17" in line 23 and ending at the words "City of Seattle" in line 27.
IV. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph III, he admits that the petitioner is of sound mind.
V. That he denies the allegations set forth in paragraph IV of said petition.
VI. That he admits the allegations set forth in paragraph V of said petition, ending at the words "arrest hereto annexed" in line 25.
VII. That he denies each and every allegation set forth in paragraph VI of said petition.
As an Affirmative Defense to the Petition and Writ, the Commissioner of Immigration Alleges:

That the petitioner was arrested and held by the Commissionr of Immgration for deportation on the ground that he was a person likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry into the United States, and that he was given a fair hearing according to the Immigration Law on January 6, 1913, and that a complete carboncopy of the testimony taken at the hearing, and all the evidence adduced at the hearing before the Examining Inspector, ad the recommendation of the Inspector are marked "Ex. A" and made a part of this return, and that the warrant of arrest and the order of deportation are marked, respectively, "Ex. B." and "Ex. C." and made a part of this return; that as appears from said exhibits after a fair hearing it was determined on the testimony adduced that the petitioner be deported on the ground that he was likley to become a public charge.
Wherefore said Henry M. white prays the above entitled court that the said writ be dismissed and the applciation and petition therefor be denied.
In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington
In the Matter of the Application of Antonio Bisegna, alias Disegna, for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Return and Answer to the Petition for and the Writ of Habeas Corpus
Filed in the U.S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington Northern Division FEB 20 1914 Frank L. Crosby By EML Deputy
